sentences.sentence: “And how did you get your clue( 线索 )?”
“Ah, I’ll tell you all about it.
The first difficulty which we had to struggle with was finding out this American’s previous history.
Some people would have waited until their advertisements( 告示 ) were answered, or until someone came forward and gave information.
That is not Tobias Gregson’s way of going to work.
You remember the hat beside the dead man?”
“Yes,” said Holmes, “by John Underwood and Sons, 129, Camberwell Road.”
“I had no idea that you noticed that,” Gregson said, looking quite upset.
“Have you been there?”
“No.”
“Ha!” cried Gregson, in a relieved voice, “you should never neglect( 忽略 ) a chance, however small it may seem.”
“To a great mind, nothing is little,” remarked Holmes.
“Well, I went to Underwood, and asked him if he had sold a hat of that size and description.
He looked over his books, and found it at once.
He had sold the hat to a Mr. Drebber, living at Charpentier’s Boarding Establishment( 住宅 ), Torquay Terrace.
Thus I got at his address.”
“Smart—very smart!” said Sherlock Holmes.
“I next called upon Madame Charpentier,” continued the detective.
“I found her very pale and distressed( 紧张的 ).
Her daughter was in the room, too—a very fine girl she is, too.
She was looking red about the eyes and her lips shook as I spoke to her.
That didn’t escape my notice.
I sensed that something was wrong.
You know the feeling, Mr. Sherlock Holmes, when you come upon the right scent( 线索 )—a kind of excitement in your nerves( 精神 ).
‘Have you heard of the mysterious( 神秘的 ) death of your late tenant( 租户 ) Mr. Enoch J. Drebber, of Cleveland?’ I asked.
The mother nodded. She didn’t seem able to get out a word.
The daughter burst into tears. I felt more than ever that these people knew something of the matter.
‘When did Mr. Drebber leave your house for the train?’ I asked.
‘At eight o’clock,’ the mother said.
‘His secretary, Mr. Stangerson, said that there were two trains—one at 9.15 and one at 11. He was to catch the first.’
‘And was that the last time you saw him?’
A terrible change came over the woman’s face as I asked the question.
It was some seconds before she could get out the single word ‘Yes’—and when it did come, it was in a deep unnatural tone( 语调 ).
There was silence for a moment, and then the daughter spoke in a calm clear voice.
‘No good can ever come of lies, mother,’ she said.
‘Let us be honest with this gentleman. We did see Mr. Drebber again.’
‘God forgive you!’ cried Madame Charpentier, throwing up her hands and sinking back in her chair. ‘You have murdered your brother.’
‘Arthur would rather that we spoke the truth,’ the girl answered firmly.
‘You had best tell me all about it now,’ I said.
‘Besides, you do not know how much we know of it.’
‘Alice!’ cried her mother, and then, turning to me, ‘I will tell you everything, sir.
Do not think that my fear comes from me thinking that he has committed the crime.
He is utterly innocent of it.
My fear is, however, that in your eyes and in the eyes of others he may appear to be under suspicion( 嫌疑 ).
However, that is surely impossible.
His high character, his profession( 职业 ), his whole life history would all make it impossible.’
‘Your best plan is to tell me everything that happened,’ I answered.
‘If your son is innocent, he will be none the worse.’
‘Mr. Drebber has been with us for nearly three weeks.
He and his secretary, Mr. Stangerson, had been travelling on the Continent.
I noticed a ‘Copenhagen’ label( 标签 ) upon each of their trunks, showing that that had been their last stopping place.
Stangerson was a quiet, shy man, but his employer was very different.
He was rude and cruel.
Even on the night of his arrival, he got very drunk.
After noon, he could hardly ever be said to be sober( 清醒的 ).
His behavior towards the maid-servants( 侍女 ) was horribly rude.
Worst of all, he quickly assumed the same attitude towards my daughter and spoke to her in an insulting( 无礼的 ) way.
On one occasion he actually grabbed( 抓住 ) her in his arms and embraced( 抱住 ) her—an outrage( 暴行 ) which caused his own secretary to rebuke( 指责 ) him for his disgusting conduct.’
‘But why did you stand all this,’ I asked.
‘I suppose that you can get rid of your tenants( 租户 ) when you wish.’
Mrs. Charpentier blushed( 脸红 ).
‘How I wish I had! But I was tempted.
They were paying a pound a day each—fourteen pounds a week, and this is the slack( 萧条的 ) season.
I am a widow( 寡妇 ), and my boy in the Navy has cost me a lot of money.
I didn’t want to lose the income.
However, insulting( 羞辱 ) my daughter was too much, and I asked him to leave on account of it.
That was the reason for his going.’
‘Well?’
‘My heart grew light when I saw him drive away.
My son is on leave just now, but I did not tell him anything of all this, for his temper( 脾气 ) is violent, and he is fond of his sister.
When I closed the door behind them, a load seemed to be lifted from my mind.
But, in less than an hour, there was a ring at the bell, and I learned that Mr. Drebber had returned.
He was very excited, and drunk.
He forced his way into the room, where I was sitting with my daughter, and made some remark about having missed his train.
He then turned to Alice, and proposed( 提议 ) to her that she should run away with him. ‘You are old enough,’ he said, ‘and there is no law to stop you.
I have enough money to spare. Never mind the old lady here, but come along with me now. You will live like a princess( 公主 ).’
Poor Alice was so frightened( 受惊的 ) that she ran away from him, but he caught her by the wrist and tried to pull her towards the door.
I shouted, and at that moment my son Arthur came into the room.
I do not know what happened then.
I was too scared( 害怕 ) to raise my head.
When I did look up, I saw Arthur standing in the doorway laughing, with a stick in his hand.
‘I don’t think that fellow will trouble us again,’ he said.
‘I will just go after him and see what he does with himself.’
With those words he took his hat and started off down the street.
The next morning we heard of Mr. Drebber’s mysterious( 神秘的 ) death.’ ”

article_info.previous: Holmes紧接对离开的老太太进行了跟踪，但这位神秘人物却在坐出租马车的中途人间蒸发了。困扰之时，一群流浪小孩却找上门来，原来这居然是Holmes的侦探小分队。同时，Gregson探员却突然宣称自己已经将凶手绳之以法了，那么他是怎么“侦破”这起案件的呢？
article_info.share_words: “I will just go after him and see what he does with himself.” With those words he took his hat and started off down the street.The next morning we heard of Mr. Drebber’s mysterious death.

question.cn: 为什么当侦探询问关于Mr. Drebber的死讯时，这位母亲看上去很害怕？
question.en: Why did the mother look terrified when the detective asked about the death of Mr. Drebber ?

options.cn: 因为她的女儿杀了Mr. Drebber。
options.en: Because her daughter killed Mr. Drebber.

options.cn: 因为她害怕他的儿子被认作是凶手。
options.en: Because she feared that her son might be recognized as the murderer.

analysis: 文中这位母亲说到“My fear is, however, that in your eyes and in the eyes of others he may appear to be under suspicion. ” 说明她担心自己的儿子会有杀人嫌疑，故选C项。

question.cn: 根据这位母亲的描述，Mr. Drebber行为举止如何？
question.en: According to the mother, what was Mr. Drebber’s behavior like?

analysis: 文中这位母亲说到Mr. Drebber时说“He was rude and cruel . . . His behavior towards the maid-servants was horribly rude.” 说明是Mr. Drebber无礼又凶狠，故选C项。

question.cn: 为什么Mrs. Charpentier并没有赶走自己的租客？
question.en: Why didn’t Mrs. Charpentier get rid of her tenants?

options.cn: 因为她不想失去这笔收入。
options.en: Because she didn’t want to lose the income.

options.cn: 因为她特别喜欢她的租客。
options.en: Because she liked her tenants a lot.

analysis: 文中提到“I am a widow, and my boy in the Navy has cost me a lot of money. I didn’t want to lose the income. ” 说明Mrs. Charpentier并不想失去这笔收入，故选A项。

question.cn: 当Mr. Drebber回到房子时他想做什么？
question.en: What did Mr. Drebber want to do when he returned to the house?

options.en: He wanted to wait for his secretary.
He wanted to take Mrs. Charpentier’s daughter away.
He wanted to pay the rent.

analysis: 文中描述Mr. Drebber再次回来时“He then turned to Alice, and proposed to her that she should run away with him” 说明他想把Mrs. Charpentier的女儿带走，故选B项。

question.cn: 从今天的故事中我们可以得知什么？
question.en: What can we know from today’s story ?

options.en: Detective Gregson thought Arthur Charpentier was the murderer.

analysis: 通读全文可知，Gregson侦探认为Arthur有杀人动机，且通过他的描述，Arthur杀人的可能性很大，故选A项。BC选项都不符合文意。

share_title: 100天读完4本英文书，今天是第11天
